issues.title: yum_repository does not properly invalidate the DNF package cache
issues.body:
## Description
When setting up a yum_repository on a Fedora host with DNF we're not properly invalidating Chef's cache of packages available to DNF as we do with yum.

## Chef Version
13.7.4 (current)

## Platform Version
Fedora 26

## Replication Case
Setup a repo 
Install a package from that repo

1st run will fail. Second run will work fine.

commits.message:
Add the same logic to other actions

Missed that entirely

Signed-off-by: Tim Smith <tsmith@chef.io>

Fix yum_repository to properly reload chef's package cache post repo setup

Without this you cannot install a package that is in that repository. We already did this for the yum cache, but not  for the DNF cache.

Signed-off-by: Tim Smith <tsmith@chef.io>

Merge pull request #6738 from cramaechi/CHEF-5055

Fix knife status to show seconds when needed #5055

pull_requests.title: Chef 14: Add dhparam, rsa_private_key and rsa_public_key resources
pull_requests.body:
Ported from the openssl cookbook. I've done all the major refactoring there to shake the bugs out. This is just reformatted to use the mixin instead of a cookbook helper and to be library style so it works in core chef.

Signed-off-by: Tim Smith <tsmith@chef.io>

pull_requests.title: Chef 14: Remove knife index rebuild command that requires Chef < 11
pull_requests.body:
knife index rebuild only works on Chef Server < 11. We no longer support
Chef Server 10 and anyone still using 10 should use an older DK or gem
install of chef for management.

Signed-off-by: Tim Smith <tsmith@chef.io>

pull_requests.title: Chef 14: Remove deprecated -r option for Solo mode
pull_requests.body:
We claimed we were going to remove this in Chef 13. Let's stop rewriting
ARGs now.

Signed-off-by: Tim Smith <tsmith@chef.io>

pull_requests.title: Chef 14: Remove previously deprecated mixins and Chef::DSL::Recipe::FullDSL
pull_requests.body:
We wired these up previously with deprecations. They've been deprecated for a long time and are pretty rarely used on the Supermarket. Additionally we have Foodcritic rules to detect their usage:

FC102: Deprecated Chef::DSL::Recipe::FullDSL class used
FC100: Deprecated Chef::Mixin::Language mixin used
FC099: Deprecated Chef::Mixin::LanguageIncludeRecipe mixin used
FC098: Deprecated Chef::Mixin::RecipeDefinitionDSLCore mixin used
FC097: Deprecated Chef::Mixin::LanguageIncludeAttribute mixin used

Signed-off-by: Tim Smith <tsmith@chef.io>

pull_requests.title: Add Ruby 2.5 testing to Travis
pull_requests.body:
Time to get started

Signed-off-by: Tim Smith <tsmith@chef.io>

pull_requests.title: Apt repo cleanup and testing expansion
pull_requests.body: So this all started when @coderanger pointed out that we didn't need to use the run_command on the shell_out helper method since it does that internally already. I fixed that here and realized the logic could be broken out to ease readability and expand testing. I added yard comments, broke out some logic into smaller methods, added more unit tests, and added a bit more debug logging.

## Description

If you dynamically set the log level in your run using `Chef::Log.level = :debug`, and then later notify the `ohai` resource, the loglevel will be reset to `info`.

## Chef Version
12.21.26

## Platform Version
CentOS 7

## Replication Case
Using this recipe:

```
ohai 'etc' do
    plugin 'etc'
    action :nothing
end
Chef::Log.level = :debug
log 'test 1' do

    notifies :reload, 'ohai[etc]', :immediately
end
log 'test 2' do

end 
```

issues.title: `file` can't handle enforcing permissions on special devices
issues.body:
## Description

`file` resource bails out on char, block, socket files, etc. - even if not context is specified.

However, a `file` resource is the logical way to enforce file ownership and permissions on such files. Cause they're files, because unix.

## Chef Version
12.21.26

## Platform Version
RHEL

## Replication Case
```
chef-apply -e 'file "/dev/zero" do owner "root" end'
```

## Client Output
```
File /dev/zero exists, but is a char device, set force_unlink to true to remove
```

issues.title: dnf_package doesn't handle multiarch properly
issues.body:
## Description

Given two arches, it gets confused

Example:

```
dnf_package 'glib2' do
  package_name ['glib2'] * 2
  arch ['x86_64', 'i686']
  action :upgrade
end
```

What you will find is that it will always try to install glib2-${version}.x86_64 and glib2-${version}.i686 because it compares both to the string it gets back from the helper which doesn't include the arch.

Output:

```

issues.title: Chef_gem installation from custom source does not reset source list properly
issues.body:
## Description
Given the following setup: 
* Air-gapped environment
* Local ruby gem repository (linked to rubygems.org)
* `client.rb` has a defined `rubygems_url` to the lokal rubygems repository
 
This works so far. But whenever we install a ruby gem via `chef_gem` resource, it always takes 3 minutes until completion. The only way it works immediatly is, if we use the `clear_sources` flag to set it to true.

Our investigations showed that whenever an installation source is specified, the default `rubygems url` (rubygems.org) is used. It would be possible to set the `clear_sources` flag to clean the `rubygems_url` list and to avoid this problem, but that can not be made for shared cookbooks (such as push_jobs, etc). 

## Chef Version
Client: 13.6.4

## Platform Version
Linux, Red Hat 7.4

## Replication Case

* Ensure an air-gapped client
* Define a custom `rubygems_url` (via `client.rb`)
* Run the following snipped that installs a not existing ruby gems

```
chef_gem 'chef-ruby-lvm' do
  action [ :remove, :install ]
  # clear_source true # uncomment to fix the 3min timeout. 
end
```

The same behaviour can be faced by using `gem install` directly.

**3 Minutes installation duration:**
```
gem install --source http://rubygems.mycustomer.local/repository/rubygems mixlib-install --verbose
...
unable to pull data from https://rubygems.org/': timed out (https://api.rubygems.org/specs.4.8.gz)
1 gem installed
```

**Instant installation duration:** 
```
gem install --clear-sources --source http://rubygems.mycustomer.local/repository/rubygems mixlib-install --verbose
```

## Client Output

The behaviour without the `clear_sources` (with 3 minutes duration) is as follows:

```
[2017-12-14T12:19:26+01:00] DEBUG: chef_gem[chef-ruby-lvm] no installed version found for chef-ruby-lvm (>= 0)
[2017-12-14T12:19:26+01:00] DEBUG: found gem chef-ruby-lvm version 0.3.0 for platform ruby from 
[2017-12-14T12:19:26+01:00] DEBUG: chef_gem[chef-ruby-lvm] chef-ruby-lvm not installed, installing 0.3.0
[2017-12-14T12:22:26+01:00] INFO: chef_gem[chef-ruby-lvm] installed chef-ruby-lvm at 0.3.0
[32m- install version 0.3.0 of package chef-ruby-lvm[0m
[0m[2017-12-14T12:22:26+01:00] DEBUG: chef_gem[chef-ruby-lvm] resetting gem environment to default
```

issues.title: Catch Errno::EINVAL in ConfigFetcher
issues.body:
<!--- 
!!!!!! NOTE: CHEF CLIENT BUGS ONLY !!!!!!

This issue tracker is for the code contained within this repo -- `chef-client`, base `knife` functionality (not
plugins), `chef-apply`, `chef-solo`, `chef-client -z`, etc.

* Requests for new or alternative functionality should be made to [feedback.chef.io](https://feedback.chef.io/forums/301644-chef-product-feedback/category/110832-chef-client)
* [Chef Server issues](https://github.com/chef/chef-server/issues/new)
* [ChefDK issues](https://github.com/chef/chef-dk/issues/new)
* Cookbook Issues (see the https://github.com/chef-cookbooks repos or search [Supermarket](https://supermarket.chef.io) or GitHub/Google)

-->

## Description
<!--- Briefly describe the issue -->
We can call `chef-client` with `-j` and a file path. But if we try passing a JSON string instead, on Windows, we get an exception trace mentioning `Errno::EINVAL`. In the source code, there are already checks for `Errno::ENOENT` and `Errno::EACCES`, so perhaps we could report a nice error here as well?

I understand from https://github.com/chef/chef/issues/6721 that this behavior is not supported, but it would be nice with a better error message.

## Chef Version
<!--- Tell us which version of chef-client you are using (see below for Server+ChefDK bugs). -->
Chef v12 and v13

## Platform Version
<!--- Tell us which Operating System distribution and version chef-client is running on. -->
Windows Server 2012 R2 and 2016

## Replication Case
<!--- Tell us what steps to take to replicate your problem.  See [How to create a Minimal, Complete, and Verifiable example](https://stackoverflow.com/help/mcve)
for information on how to create a good replication case. -->

I used a cookbook `testjson` with a recipe and attribute like this:

```
>type recipes\default.rb
attr1_value = node['testjson']['attr1']
file 'C:\Users\Administrator\generated-by-chef.txt' do
  content attr1_value
end

>type attributes\default.rb
default['testjson']['attr1'] = 'default value'
```

Observe that `chef-client -z -o "recipe[testjson::default]"` works as expected.

Create a JSON file like this:
```
echo {"testjson": {"attr1": "value from file"}} > myattr.json
```

Observe that `chef-client -z -o "recipe[testjson::default]" -j myattr.json` works.

Then try with inline JSON:

`chef-client -z -o "recipe[testjson::default]" -j '{"testjson": {"attr1": "inline value"}}'`


## Client Output
<!--- The relevant output of the chef-client run or a link to a gist of the entire run, if there is one.

The debug output (chef-client -l debug) may be useful, but please link to a gist, or truncate it. -->

## Stacktrace
<!--- Please include the stacktrace.out output or link to a gist of it, if there is one. -->

Abbreviated output:
```
.../config_fetcher.rb:47:in `read': Invalid argument @ rb_sysopen - {"testjson":{"attr1":"value from json"}} (Errno::EINVAL)
```

which comes from `read_local_config` in lib/chef/config_fetcher.rb
https://github.com/chef/chef/blob/master/lib/chef/config_fetcher.rb

issues.title: gem_package gem_binary cannot be omitted with Chef client v13
issues.body:
<!--- 
!!!!!! NOTE: CHEF CLIENT BUGS ONLY !!!!!!

This issue tracker is for the code contained within this repo -- `chef-client`, base `knife` functionality (not

-->

## Description
The documentation for the `gem_package` resource, https://docs.chef.io/resource_gem_package.html , makes it sound like the `gem_binary` property is optional:

```
A property for the gem_package provider that is used to specify a gems binary.
By default, the same version of Ruby that is used by the chef-client will be installed.
```

I have a recipe with a block like this:

```
gem_package 'my_gem' do
  action :install
  source 'my-artifact-repository'
end
```

I can run kitchen converge fine with Chef client 12. But with Chef client 13, I get an error like this:

```
Chef::Exceptions::ValidationFailed: Property gem_binary must be one of String!  
You passed false.
```

I have tested with Chef client 13.2.20-1 and 13.4.19-1.

See also https://github.com/chef/chef-web-docs/issues/1169

I have tested with Chef client 13.2.20-1 and 13.4.19-1.

Windows Server 2012 R2, both workstation and Kitchen instances

issues.title: Change default behavior of non-interval runs to --no-fork
issues.body:
If we're only running in any sort of one-shot mode, we don't need to fork.

Causes issues and needless complexity with things like chef_client_updater and automate.

pull_requests.title: Yum refactor
pull_requests.body:
- removes yum-dump.py
- halves peak memory utilization
- removes the YumCache
- introduces a long-lived python helper that does most of the work of RPM comparisons, etc on the python side using the actual RPM libs
- implements things like `yum_package "foo < 1.2.3" do allow_downgrade true end` correctly
- implements things like `yum_package "perl(Git)"` correctly (impossible with the old YumCache)
- closes most of the old yum_package issues

My recipe looks like:
```
# recipes/database.rb
include_recipe 'sql_server::server'

```

default['sql_server']['accept_eula'] = true
default['sql_server']['version'] = '2016'
```

I have a workaround - I simply ran:

```
C:\Users\chef-user>certutil -hashfile C:\Users\chef-user\Downloads\SQLEXPR_x64_ENU.exe SHA256
SHA256 hash of file C:\Users\chef-user\Downloads\SQLEXPR_x64_ENU.exe:
2a 5b 64 ae 64 a8 28 5c 02 48 70 ec 46 43 61 7a c5 14 68 94 dd 59 dd 56 0e 75 ce a7 87 bf 93 33
CertUtil: -hashfile command completed successfully.
```

Note that the checksum is the same - but all lower case.

So I modified my attributes:

```
# attributes/default.rb
default['sql_server']['accept_eula'] = true
default['sql_server']['version'] = '2016'
# ABr: bug in chef - checksum is not matching (case mismatch problem??)
default['sql_server']['server']['checksum'] = '2a5b64ae64a8285c024870ec4643617ac5146894dd59dd560e75cea787bf9333'
```

Then re-ran chef-client and all is well.

issues.title: knife Bootstrap permissions error is misleading
issues.body:
## Description
On bootstrapping a windows node , the message 

ERROR: You authenticated successfully to https://'''chef-server-url''' as '''user''' but you are not authorized for this action.
Response:  missing create permission

is displayed. This is not because <user> authenticated correctly or because the <user> is missing the create permission. It is because using user-credentials on a bootstrap, recreates the client and node -- stripping permissions of the existing client and node. When the "clients" group is not part of the READ+CREATE ACL of the nodes container, the recreated client cannot create the new node required for the bootstrap. Thus the missing create permission message. 

The error message is very misleading and cost me over two days of developer time -- it should be rewritten to provide more detail to what exactly is missing permission. Instead of indicating that the user authenticated correctly and display a missing permissions error interpreted as relevant to the user specified. This is very confusing as the user can be part of the admins group and seemingly have their permissions stripped from them.

## Chef Version
13.6.4 ( chefdk - 2.4.17-1_amd64.deb)

## Platform Version
Ubuntu 14.04

## Replication Case
Reference stackoverflow - https://stackoverflow.com/questions/47780723/cant-bootstrap-node-when-user-is-in-admin-group/47819382#47819382

Remove the clients group from the READ+CREATE ACL of containers nodes.

Attempt to bootstrap a remote node with user credentials.

## Client Output
ERROR: You authenticated successfully to https://'''chef-server-url''' as '''user''' but you are not authorized for this action.
Response:  missing create permission

## Stacktrace
https://gist.github.com/marseille/9eb5ba3a79b353fbeb75855ebab38ae7#file-gistfile1-txt-L3

pull_requests.title: [MSYS-724] Chef::Util::Windows::LogonSession should allow having only the prescribed users permissions
pull_requests.body:
### Description

While finishing https://github.com/chef/chef/pull/5832,  we changed the logon type in `Chef::Util::Windows::LogonSession` from `LOGON32_LOGON_NETWORK` to `LOGON32_LOGON_NEW_CREDENTIALS` to facilitate passing credentials to a remote system without logging in locally using those credentials, to handle a use case where those credentials were valid on the remote system but not on the local system.
However, this means that `Chef::Mixin::UserContext.with_user_context` might log on to the local system as a new user but continue using the old users token and thus the old/original users privileges.
`Chef::ReservedNames::Win32::Security.has_admin_privileges?` is really looking to see if we're elevated, not 'admin' per se. We should print some debug information about the token like if it is elevated. With this information you'll see that when we run chef from an elevated shell, we still have an elevated token even if we run `has_admin_privileges?` from inside `with_user_context` using a regular user.
The above functionality was masked by this line in the before block in ```spec\functional\win32\security_spec.rb:
allow(Chef::ReservedNames::Win32::Security).to receive(:OpenProcessToken).and_return(true)```
This caused the 'running as non admin user' test to pass even though it should fail. Fixing this might be hard, because a regular user cannot use much of the functionality in `has_admin_privileges`, maybe not even calling `open_current_process_token`. One solution might be catching the access denied results and returning false, presuming that if we get an access denied in this area then we aren't elevated.

Note that we reverted the functional tests in https://github.com/chef/chef/pull/6588 due odd behavior on Appveyor.

### Acceptance Criteria

- [x] able to run a ruby block with only the privileges of another user, while preserving the functionality needed by remote_file.
- [x] `Chef::ReservedNames::Win32::Security.has_admin_privileges?` prints a debug message that contains token elevation information.
- [x] The Chef::Win32::Security functional test for running as a non-admin user that was reverted is returned and does not return a false positive.
- [x] The functional tests pass on appveyor or we have a documented reason to exclude them on appveyor. 

### Check List

- [x] New functionality includes tests
- [x] All tests pass
- [ ] RELEASE\_NOTES.md, has been updated if required (not required for bugfixes, required for API changes)
- [x] All commits have been signed-off for the Developer Certificate of Origin. See <https://github.com/chef/chef/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#developer-certification-of-origin-dco>

pull_requests.title: Add sensitive to registry_key (fixes #5695)
pull_requests.body:
### Description

This PR adds the `sensitive` property to `registry_key` but needs some help before it's ready to be merged.

I'm not sure if the `sensitive: true` sets the `values` property to default to sensitive or if when `sensitive` is true on the resource, `values` will be masked.

Re tests, looking at the `execute` resource it looks like I should be copying across something like below, but not sure where it should sit.

```
    context "when sensitive is set true" do
      it "should honor sensitive attribute" do
        new_resource.sensitive true
        # Since the resource is sensitive, it should not have :live_stream set
        opts.delete(:live_stream)
        expect(provider).to receive(:shell_out_with_systems_locale!).with(new_resource.name, opts)
        expect(provider).to receive(:converge_by).with("registry_key sensitive resource").and_call_original
        expect(Chef::Log).not_to receive(:warn)
        provider.run_action(:run)
        expect(new_resource).to be_updated
      end
    end
```

### Issues Resolved

#5695

pull_requests.title: Ensure package (un)locking is idempotent
pull_requests.body:
### Description

Due to the nature of the comparison done, the `package_locked` methods
will always return false as they presume the package name is a string,
when it is in fact always coerced into an array.

Additionally in situations where the package_name is set rather than
being inherited from the package resource's name, it will always return
false.

### Issues Resolved

Resolves #6361
Resolves #6493

    => nil
